H0.text: Rainfall could reduce the water level of the Great Miami Aquifer over time if there is too much, as the aquifer lies under much of southwest Ohio.

H1.text: Pollution could reduce the water level of the Great Miami Aquifer over time, a large underground water supply that lies under much of southwest Ohio.

H2.text: Irrigation could reduce the water level of the Great Miami Aquifer, a large underground water supply that lies under much of southwest Ohio, over time.

H3.text: Evaporation is what could reduce the water level of the Great Miami Aquifer over time by too much, as the aquifer is a large underground water supply that lies under much of southwest Ohio.

A4.text: Irrigation is the primary activity causing groundwater storage loss across the U.S.

A5.text: Rising temperatures increase surface evaporation and transpiration, resulting in decreased water content of the soil.

A6.text: Overdrafting (depletion) of underground aquifers can lead to permanent loss of aquifer capacity, decreased water quality, ground subsidence, and other problems.

A7.text: The advent of diesel and electric motors led to systems that could pump groundwater out of major aquifers faster than drainage basins could refill them.
